The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jen is very responsive and organized - she seemed to be passionate and know the material.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn is super clear, and available. Interactions with her were always a pleasure and I don't really see how her teaching style could be improved. She was really great.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn is a fantastic TA. She's great at explaining things and responds very quickly to student questions and concerns, which was helpful since Jim did not. She was good at sort of translating complicated things Jim said and she was always available to help students. All in all, she's a fantastic TA who made a big difference in the quality of this class.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  I felt that our professor was a bit scattered, and Jenn really held the class together. She was also very experienced in the subject area and was a great resource.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Excellent at both explaining the material and dealing with class logistics.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was incredibly responsive and helpful! Great complement to Jim, and they worked well together in the classroom.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jen is great.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was very responsive and always answered emails promptly. She was very organized and kept us on track. She was also very knowledgeable of the topic and good at explaining the information.
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was incredibly friendly, accessible, and helpful - thank you!
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jenn was knowledgeable, approachable, and very helpful!
Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Very good job supporting the students and also filling in blanks during lecture.

Instructor: Jennifer Burlingame Hoyle Fair  Jennifer Hoyle is an excellent TA. She was able to work with us in the field, offered considerable advice and input on our project, and really added a lot to the class itself by clarifying important concepts and helping with examination preparation.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I thought the field trips were incredibly valuable; I learned a tremendous amount from Jim out in the field.

The field trips were great but there could have been more, particularly to material in the second half. Most of the streams we did visit were pretty pristine, but it would have been interesting to go to a wetlands or dam or more urban streams.

Jim is a GEM! This is one of the best courses that I've taken at FES. He is so generous with his time and knowledge. Who else at FES would give up all of their weekends for most of the fall to assist in student projects? Unbelievable! The passion he has for this field is contagious! I loved this class!!

Jim's lectures can be hard to follow for three hours. It's great that he loves his career and is so excited to pass on what he's learned to us, but sometimes he gets too "into the weeds" and uses terms that make it easy for the non-engineers among us to tune out. Overall the class was very interesting, but I wish we could have taken more field trips. The essays assigned were very helpful, and I probably learned just as much from them as I did from the lectures. The final essay was very thought provoking and fun to write, but it didn't sum up the last half of the semester like I hoped it would. I wish there was a way to test our knowledge of the second half's content like there was for the first. It wouldn't necessarily have to be a formal test, but perhaps writing several shorter essays would help.

Overall a great course. I felt it could be OK for homework assignments could be a little more specific or rigorous - there is a lot of potential material that the course covers, but a lot of it is not required to commit to memory or use to complete the course. It could be OK to require more.

It was a great course and was well taught. The reason I gave the course a "4" on question 15 (how valuable to students with interests similar to mine) is that I felt like it did not cover several topics of keen interest to MF candidates interested in forest management. I would have liked to see more about forest roads and their interactions with streams and hydrology, and bioengineering, or the use of plants in restoration.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field trips and the river restoration paper.
Group projects were a great opportunity to develop a portfolio-quality work and to gain first-hand experience in the assessment of a river reach.

It was great that this material was very hands on. It covered a lot of stuff and was a very good overview of fluvial geomorphology and river restoration. It was cool that it was project based and even though I wish we went into more details on some things, we really did learn a lot.
The assignments were crucial in understanding what we were meant to take away from lectures.
Jim's a clear speaker, and the material was very useful in better understanding how rivers/streams work and react to change.
Hard to pick a favorite part. The lectures were excellent and very informative. The field trips were also well selected, and the group project have you a good opportunity to be hands-on in the field.
Great overview of theory and practice in stream restoration and management.
The field trips and group project.
Everything. This is one of the best courses at FES.
Field trips and project format was very useful
Field trips
Field trips were great-- loved applying classroom material to real-life situations.
Field trips and lecture were equally great.

Jim's wealth of practical experience. He is a contrast to many acadmemics - he has actually done what he teaches for the better part of 4 decades. He had great stories and a clear presentation style. The field trips and final project gave us some experience on some of the field techniques. I particularly enjoyed the final exam/essay. The choice of topic was fascinating (even for people interested in other disciplines), and the open-ended opportunity to go where we wanted with it made it an excellent capstone to the course. I thought the articles for the final exam were excellent and very interesting. As a result, I would say that this assignment ranks among the best of my time at F&ES.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I thought the mid-term required knowledge of a lot of not very useful information - it required more memorization than critical thinking.

It would be better if it were taught in shorter lectures twice a week (but that may not be possible). I sometimes wish we spent a little more time on the second half of the class. We spent more time on fluvial morphology and then channel design, then things like drought, flooding, dams... than I would have liked. Also, sometimes I felt like there was a lot of information without always the amount of detail into each topic that I'd like. Some of the workflows and steps for restoration sometimes felt repetitive or unhelpful without more on the ground examples

The lectures lacked hierarchy of information, I think summarizing the key take away focus points could have been helpful. 3 hour lecture is a difficult format for learning, so warning us as to the key issues in each lecture would have been helpful.. Jim does a great job of giving this history of each topic, but important information can get lost in the background in a 3 hour lecture. The assignments often felt as if they came out of nowhere, and I had to return to the lectures and search for the information.
Near the end of the semester a few of the lectures got a bit repetitive; would have liked a little more practice with some of the equations.
I think the writing assignments could be greatly improved. I would suggest making them shorter with more clearly designed essay questions.

I would have liked to see more related to forestry. I know there were several of us interested in forestland hydrology and restoration work related to forestry. I think we could have had less quantitative exercises (even though I normally like quantitative work) and less about dam removal. As interesting as dam removal is, and recognizing that many students called for it to be a focus of the last weeks of the course, I am left wondering how many of us will actually ever do any work related to it. On the other hand, many of us who are MF candidates will only take this course on hydrology/rivers. This was our only opportunity to learn (in school) about how this subject relates to a field we will practice. I can see in my work having to make decisions regarding roads, bank stabilization, and hydrology - it would have been nice to gain more exposure to the use of plants and to the effects of forest operations and management on streams and hydrology.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: A couple discussion sections would have been helpful.
It was effective. Project field trips could be a little better planned.
The course was well integrated with the lab components.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm getting an MF and my advisor suggested I incorporate this class. I think a general understanding of restoration approaches is very useful for land managers and others working on restoration efforts.
Great look at important/emerging element of water resources management.
This is a nice addition to my forestry degree, though it never really directly related to forestry. I think this class will be useful regardless of what job I take on after graduation.
This course was a step in a new direction for me, about opening new avenues.
I am a second-year MF candidate. This is the only water-related course I will take (in either undergraduate or graduate school).

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I'm getting an MF and my advisor suggested I incorporate this class. I think a general understanding of restoration approaches is very useful for land managers and others working on restoration efforts.
To get exposure to how rivers are thought of by scientists in terms of health and of physical/biological processes.

I'm interested in water resources more broadly and though I'm more interested in rivers out west (and all associated problems), this is one of the only classes at Yale that covers fluvial morphology in detail. It's also one of the only classes at Yale in this topic and on ecosystem restoration.
I had never taken a course on geomorphology/restoration/river processes/hydrolics/etc. so it was a good overview.
Felt that it was necessary to understand stream form and function for anyone seeking to do conservation work.
IMportant to career expertise
Practical overview of an area that fits into many of my interests.
To learn about river processes and restoration! I may want to do restoration work in the future.
The course had excellent reviews from last year's students. I felt the need to broaden and deepen my understanding of water-related subjects.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: In a general way, yes; I think it was a great conceptual course and it's great to have the textbook as a reference material.
YES
I learned a lot in this class and it clarified a lot of my interests for me. I wish we had spent more time on degraded streams, but even so I twas really engaged and I'm glad I took it.
Yes
Yes.
Absolutely
Yes.
Yes
For the most part, yes.
Yes

I expected to learn more about river processes in the context of forestry or natural environments, but this class focused more on urban stream restoration. There were several students in the class interested in water quality as it relates to logging, and I still feel like I'm missing that knowledge even after the course.
Yes.

Partly. I think the first half of the course was what I expected to learn, and it was very well done. The final weeks on dam removal and fish passage were well taught, but I did not have much interest in these subjects. As a forestry student, I would have hoped to see more about the effects of forestry on water and streams, and ways I can improve my practice in the future. I doubt I'll ever get to weigh in on a dam removal, though I may be wrong. Overall, despite this, I feel that the course was very good.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was a very applied project and I learned a lot about the application of some of the concepts we went over in class.
I was very lucky to be in a group I knew and liked working with (same page about when to turn in assignments, preparation, drafting style etc). Not always the case for group work at FES.

The group project was interesting and it was a nice way to get hands on experience in things that would not have been possible to accomplish alone. But when it's such a big thing and big component of the class, it sometimes makes it difficult because one needs to constantly plan and work around other people.
More enjoyable, allowed us to divide and conquer
My teammates were not motivated and difficult to schedule.
It was great. I learned a lot and our group worked well together.
Nice to learn from others' expertise; writing papers as a team is always challenging, but looking at past examples helped us craft a workable outline.

The course project. It was useful for self driven work, but the group dynamic lacked focus and in my opinion was a little immature. As I am a first year, this was kind of bewildering at first but I came to understand I needed to make sure the project was successful. This was in part because I was in a group that had designed its own project. On the other hand, the pre-designed projects seemed to simplistic to me - for instance doing an assessment of an area seemed very entry level, and I wanted to do something more interesting.

The group work in this class worked pretty well. Usually, group projects end up with one or two students doing everything. I was able to incorporate my work on a management plan into this course, so the effort was well balanced and integrated.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Pick a really cool project you're excited about to work on throughout the semester; it's a great way to get involved in a cool restoration project and there is a lot of support from Jim and Jen.
Make sure to take lots of notes during the field trips.
Be sure to think of an interesting project that really engages you because it does take up a lot of the work load.
Take the course. Design your project carefully
Very practical class if you're interested in this field. To get the most out of it, try to do the readings.
It is a great class, especially for those interested in water/hydrology

If you are interested in urban rivers, absolutely take the class. Even if you are an MF or MFs this is a good course, but don't expect it to be your hardest or most valuable class. It's always great to learn from a practitioner, and given that there are few of those at FES, I would recommend taking this class over one that has a more academic focus.
Take the course.

Go for it - this is an excellent course taught by a great teacher. For MF students: you will learn a lot about hydrology and river processes, but don't expect much focus on forestry. For this you'll have to study outside of class.
